Title:
Pseudomonas syringae causing angular leaf spot on various
cucurbits are members of genomospecies 1.
Abstract:
Angular leaf spot caused by Pseudomonas syringae is the
most widespread bacterial disease of various cucurbit crops. Reports of
Pseudomonas syringae pvs. lachrymans, aptata, syringae, savastanoi, and
tabaci as cucurbit pathogens indicates that a broader diversity of
organisms within P. syringae may be responsible for this disease than
previously recognized. In this study we collected 27 P. syringae strains
over several years from watermelon, cantaloupe, and squash hosts in
Florida, Georgia, and California. Strains were fluorescent on KingÂ’s
medium B agar and displayed the typical phenotypic and biochemical
characteristics of P. syringae. Phylogenetic analysis using four
housekeeping genes (gyrB, rpoD, gapA, gltA) indicated that P. syringae
strains infecting cucurbits were distributed among three clades within
genomospecies 1 (phylogroup 2a, 2b, and 2d), and were phylogenetically
distinct from P. syringae pv. lachrymans which is in genomospecies 2 (P.
amygdali). One strain recovered from cantaloupe was found to be a member
of genomospecies 2, and displayed limited host range and virulence. The
identification of identical multilocus haplotypes recovered from
Florida, Georgia, and California over multiple years suggests the
potential dispersion of the pathogen through seed. Pathogenicity tests
show that watermelon, squash, and cantaloupe are susceptible to
genetically diverse P. syringae strains in genomospecies 1.
